questions.question_text: What should you do when approached by a reporter about a case that you are working on or have worked on?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Answer: (A) Refer the reporter to the attorney that retained you

Explanation:

(A) Refer the reporter to the attorney that retained you ✅ Ensures legal and ethical compliance; avoids unauthorized disclosures.
(B) Say, "no comment" ❌ May appear evasive or uncooperative; not the best professional approach.
(C) Answer all the reporter's questions as completely as possible ❌ Risks disclosing sensitive or confidential information.
(D) Answer only the questions that help your case ❌ Selective answering can lead to ethical or legal violations.

-----
If you agree, please UPVOTE.
Each time you upvote someone with contributor access (like me) your vote is added to the Community Vote Distribution, which helps the entire community.

choices.C: Answer all the reporter's questions as completely as possible
choices.A: Refer the reporter to the attorney that retained you
choices.D: Answer only the questions that help your case

choices.C: They tampered with evidence by using it
choices.B: They attempted to implicate personnel without proof
choices.D: They called in the FBI without correlating with the fingerprint data
choices.A: They examined the actual evidence on an unrelated system

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Answer: (A) They examined the actual evidence on an unrelated system

Explanation:

(A) They examined the actual evidence on an unrelated system ✅ Violates forensic principles; risks contamination or alteration of evidence.
(B) They attempted to implicate personnel without proof ❌ No evidence in the scenario suggests premature accusations were made.
(C) They tampered with evidence by using it ❌ Running the disk on an isolated system is not tampering but improper handling.
(D) They called in the FBI without correlating with the fingerprint data ❌ Calling the FBI is appropriate for major incidents, regardless of fingerprint data.

-----
If you agree, please UPVOTE.
Each time you upvote someone with contributor access (like me) your vote is added to the Community Vote Distribution, which helps the entire community.

questions.question_text: A state department site was recently attacked and all the servers had their disks erased. The incident response team sealed the area and commenced investigation. During evidence collection they came across a zip disks that did not have the standard labeling on it. The incident team ran the disk on an isolated system and found that the system disk was accidentally erased. They decided to call in the FBI for further investigation. Meanwhile, they short listed possible suspects including three summer interns. Where did the incident team go wrong?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Answer: (C) A Large volume of data can exist within the swap file of which the computer user has no knowledge

Explanation:

(A) ❌ Incorrect; system configurations are stored in the registry, not the swap file.
(B) ❌ Incorrect; the swap file is unrelated to registry communication.
(C) ✅ Correct; swap files store inactive memory data, potentially containing valuable forensic evidence.
(D) ❌ Incorrect; command history is stored separately, not in the swap file.

-----
If you agree, please UPVOTE.
Each time you upvote, your vote is added to the Community Vote Distribution, which helps the entire community.

choices.A: Windows stores all of the systems configuration information in this file
choices.C: A Large volume of data can exist within the swap file of which the computer user has no knowledge
choices.B: This is file that windows use to communicate directly with Registry
choices.D: This is the file that windows use to store the history of the last 100 commands that were run from the command line

questions.question_text: When investigating a Windows System, it is important to view the contents of the page or swap file because:

choices.C: Connect the target media; Prepare the system for acquisition; Secure the evidence; Copy the media
choices.D: Secure the evidence; prepare the system for acquisition; Connect the target media; copy the media
choices.B: Prepare the system for acquisition; Connect the target media; copy the media; Secure the evidence
choices.A: Connect the target media; prepare the system for acquisition; Secure the evidence; Copy the media

questions.question_text: Chris has been called upon to investigate a hacking incident reported by one of his clients. The company suspects the involvement of an insider accomplice in the attack. Upon reaching the incident scene, Chris secures the physical area, records the scene using visual media. He shuts the system down by pulling the power plug so that he does not disturb the system in any way. He labels all cables and connectors prior to disconnecting any. What do you think would be the next sequence of events?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
This approach ensures that the evidence is preserved in its original state before any acquisition or copying processes begin, which is crucial in forensic investigations.

Selected Answer: B
Step 15. Format the target hard disk on which the binary copy will be ripped.
Step 16. Connect the blocker (software or hardware) to the tested source disk with the writeprotect technology, guaranteeing data integrity.
Step 17. Make a binary (bit-by-bit) copy of the source disk for later analysis onto a blank target disk.
Step 18. Calculate a checksum (hash) of copies – authentication, which is a digital signature of
copied data, guaranteeing their fidelity necessary in the evidentiary proceedings
Step 19. Secure and pack the hard disk with the binary copy (destination) in an anti-static bag.
D. After securing the evidence, the evidence is transported to a lab, where data acquisition is prepared for and made.

As per EC Council material, next step is to remove the cables and then secure and label them. "Disconnect all wires and cables from the computer and secure them Check for any removable media and secure them if present Tag the evidence clearly and note all important details in the search and seizure evidence log Document the chain of custody"
